todos.title: Margaret Heffernan
todos.body: Dare to disagree Ted talk - YouTube.

todos.title: Yes and
todos.body: When you disagree, never say 'no', 'I disagree', 'but', instead say 'yes and''

todos.title: Right questions
todos.body: The best way to solve an argument is by learning to ask the right question.

todos.title: Don't fear conflict
todos.body: People need to feel safe and comfortable disagreeing with each other.

todos.title: Trust
todos.body: No argument can ever be solved if you don't trust the arguer.  Establish trust first, then work on reason and conclusion.

todos.title: Root problem
todos.body: Need to get to the root problem of the issue by asking the right questions.

todos.title: Process
todos.body: If you cannot agree that you will work things out, agree on a process to work things out.

todos.title: Start with reason
todos.body: For two people to get to the same conclusion they first need to find a foundational reason or outside source that they first agree with.

todos.title: Constructive conflict
todos.body: Finding people that are very different than ourselves and finding ways to engage with them.  It requires a lot of patience and a lot of energy and requires a kind of love.  You have to be prepared to change your mind.

todos.title: Show
todos.body: Construct conflict by showing, not telling.  Use multiple points of reason and past historical evidence that are concrete and real.

todos.title: Ruinous empathy
todos.body: Avoiding conflict can often be more ruinous to a relationship than if you faced conflict head first.

todos.title: Point ' counterpoint
todos.body: Arguments should enlighten, by adding information on information or reason on reason, not by getting stuck on one concept.
